body: Sounds good to me - want to open a pull request? The default is set in `VariablesChecker` in `pylint/checkers/variables.py`.

Certainly. I've created the commit, but that one character change was enough to cause two failures.

### function_redefined.py failure

The first failure is a bit baffling. ... I'm without a clue as to why my change has regressed this test.

pylint/test/functional/function_redefined.py (3, 32-42):

```
__revision__ = ''
...
def func2(): # [function-redefined]
    """docstring"""
    __revision__ = 1 # [redefined-outer-name]
    return __revision__

if __revision__:
    def exclusive_func():
        "docstring"
else:
    def exclusive_func():
        "docstring"
```

pylint/test/functional/function_redefined.txt:

```
function-redefined:15:AAAA.method2:method already defined line 12
function-redefined:18:AAAA:class already defined line 5
function-redefined:32:func2:function already defined line 29
redefined-outer-name:34:func2:Redefining name '__revision__' from outer scope (line 3)
function-redefined:51:exclusive_func2:function already defined line 45
```

Is there some sort of order, or precedence, for checkers!? My assumption is that VariablesChecker permitted the `__revision__` token, so then the checker responsible for `[redefined-outer-name]` was skipped or ignored.

### unused_variable.py failure

The second failure, is expected.

pylint/test/functional/unused_variable.py (10-16):

``` python
def test_unused_with_prepended_underscore():
    _foo = 42
    _ = 24
    __a = 24
    dummy = 24
    _a_ = 42 # [unused-variable]
    __a__ = 24 # [unused-variable]
```

pylint/test/functional/unused_variable.txt:

```
unused-variable:4:test_regression_737:Unused variable 'xml'
unused-variable:7:test_regression_923:Unused variable 'unittest.case'
unused-variable:8:test_regression_923:Unused variable 'sql'
unused-variable:15:test_unused_with_prepended_underscore:Unused variable '_a_'
unused-variable:16:test_unused_with_prepended_underscore:Unused variable '__a__'
```

The failures were consistent through all python versions (pypy and jython, not tested).

### tox output

```
======================================================================
FAIL: function_redefined (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py33/lib/python3.3/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "function_redefined":

Expected in testdata:
  34: redefined-outer-name

======================================================================
FAIL: unused_variable (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py33/lib/python3.3/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "unused_variable":

Expected in testdata:
  15: unused-variable
  16: unused-variable

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 716 tests in 35.497s
```

In regards to the `unused_variable.py` failure, assuming that it is necessary to keep those two failures, then I can just correct `dummy-variables-rgx`.

Given a setting that fixes the `unused_variable.py` failure, I would expect to also fix the `function_redfined.py` error as well. However, to me, this regression seems to indicate a peculiar coupling between the two checkers.
Hmm, I feel like I can't really help here, sorry. Let's wait until @PCManticore wakes up :wink:

Attempted this alternative: `(_+[a-zA-Z0-9_]*[a-zA-Z0-9]+?$)|dummy`

Fixes the problems experienced in https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/1058#issuecomment-237162725, but causes new issues. I'll investigate the new issues of, previously, expected `unused-variable` to see if they no longer meet those criteria. My thinking being, maybe these other tests -- in my opinion -- tested the existing, bad behavior. Or, the more likely possibility, the new regexp has borked good tests. 

I'll report back.

#### tox output

```
======================================================================
FAIL: test_functionality (pylint.testutils.LintTC)
module test of input file "func_no_dummy_redefined" (LintTC)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/testutils.py", line 273, in test_functionality
    self._test(tocheck)
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/testutils.py", line 293, in _test
    self._check_result(self.linter.reporter.finalize())
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/testutils.py", line 277, in _check_result
    got.strip()+'\n')
AssertionError: 'C:  7: Invalid constant name "value"\nW: 12:clobbering: Redefining name \'value [truncated]... != 'C:  7: Invalid constant name "value"\nW: 12:clobbering: Redefining name \'value [truncated]...
  C:  7: Invalid constant name "value"
  W: 12:clobbering: Redefining name 'value' from outer scope (line 7)
+ W: 13:clobbering: Redefining name '_' from outer scope (line 5)
+ W: 13:clobbering: Unused variable '_'


======================================================================
FAIL: lost_exception (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "lost_exception":

Unexpected in testdata:
  29: unused-variable

======================================================================
FAIL: not_in_loop (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "not_in_loop":

Unexpected in testdata:
  37: redefined-outer-name

======================================================================
FAIL: reused_outer_loop_variable (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "reused_outer_loop_variable":

Unexpected in testdata:
  36: redefined-outer-name

======================================================================
FAIL: too_many_statements (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "too_many_statements":

Unexpected in testdata:
  30: unused-variable

======================================================================
FAIL: unused_variable (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "unused_variable":

Unexpected in testdata:
  12: unused-variable

======================================================================
FAIL: useless_else_on_loop (test_functional.LintModuleTest)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/u205/work/pylint/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pylint/test/test_functional.py", line 314, in _runTest
    self.fail('\n'.join(msg))
AssertionError: Wrong results for file "useless_else_on_loop":

Unexpected in testdata:
  24: unused-variable
  49: unused-variable

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 723 tests in 31.865s

FAILED (failures=7, skipped=58)
```
My new regexp was borking on `_` which seems obvious in retrospect.

Amending my previous regexp `_+$|(_+[a-zA-Z0-9_]*[a-zA-Z0-9]+?$)|dummy` results in no errors. I'll contribute a couple lines to `unused_variable.py` and `unused_argument.py` to ensure the suggested behavior remains consistent.

issue.title: Allow underscores in unused-variables. (#1058)

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Fixes
- https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/1058
### Tests
- Additional check in `pylint/test/functional/unused_variable.py`
### Quagmire

In `pylint/test/functional/unused_argument.py`, the following line should fail; The test is, actually, incorrect.

**unused_argument.py:**

```
def test_unused(first, second, _not_used): # [unused-argument, unused-argument]
    pass
```

However. First of all, I don't know the Pylint codebase well enough know why this is either being skipped or it is marked as a pass; It shouldn't. I want to point a finger to the `pylintrc` file, but I won't be so brash. Running pylint without any arguments,  `pylint pylint/test/functional/unused_argument.py`, appears to confirm my point.
#### pylint output

```
I:  1, 0: Locally disabling missing-docstring (C0111) (locally-disabled)
I:  1, 0: Locally disabling too-few-public-methods (R0903) (locally-disabled)
W:  3,23: Unused argument 'second' (unused-argument)
W:  3,31: Unused argument '_not_used' (unused-argument)
W:  3,16: Unused argument 'first' (unused-argument)
W: 25,29: Unused argument 'aay' (unused-argument)
```

Secondly, my test would fix this broken test. With a little more knowledge on the unittest setup, I would like to break the test to demonstrate that `unused-arguments` are also fixed by my commit.
### tox

Tests have been run using the vanilla `tox` command with all tests passing, except for `jython` because I have a setup issue. I'll have to defer to the CI's judgement.

```
  py27: commands succeeded
  py33: commands succeeded
  py34: commands succeeded
  py35: commands succeeded
  pypy: commands succeeded
ERROR:   jython: InvocationError: ...omit.../python2.7 -m virtualenv --python ...omit.../jython jython (see ...omit.../jython-0.log)
  pylint: commands succeeded
```

body:
If it helps our policy in our code is `__` or `$var_` for unused variables and we're using this regex.  The last part is likely a simpler regex to achieve what is needed here for `_$var`

`dummy-variables-rgx=__|^.*[^_]_$`

issue.title: chore: normalize formatting using black and fix minor pylint warnings
issue.body:
## Proposed changes

<!--
Describe the big picture of your changes here to communicate to the maintainers why we should accept this pull request. If it fixes a bug or resolves a feature request, be sure to link to that issue.
-->

General formatting and minor pylint fixes to make sure the formatting is normalized (e.g. using one style of quotes, and not a mix, import statement order etc.)

No functionality was changed.

## Types of changes

<!--
What types of changes does your code introduce to `thin-edge.io`?
_Put an `x` in the boxes that apply_
-->

- [ ] Bugfix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New example (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [x] Improvement (general improvements like code refactoring that doesn't explicitly fix a bug or add any new functionality)
- [ ] Documentation Update (if none of the other choices apply)


## Checklist

-->

- [x] I have read the [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/thin-edge/thin-edge.io/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) doc
- [x] I have signed the [CLA](https://github.com/thin-edge/thin-edge.io/blob/main/CONTRIBUTOR-LICENSE-AGREEMENT.md) (in all commits with git commit -s)

-->
